attributes.action: Ban urban and garden pesticides to protect bees, other wildlife and human health
attributes.background: Ban the use of pesticides in urban areas & end their sale for use in gardens. There is simply no need to spray poisons in our streets, parks & gardens for cosmetic purposes, where they harm bees & other wildlife & pose a risk to human health. Safe alternatives are available, where necessary.
attributes.additional_details: Wild bees & other wildlife are in decline, a potential catastrophe for us all. Pesticides also threaten human health, many of them being carcinogens &/or neurotoxins. One way to help combat bee decline is to encourage them in urban areas. Our 22 million gardens, plus parks, road verges & other green spaces could form a network of wildlife friendly habitats. This will only work if, like France, we stop spraying pesticides in gardens and public urban spaces.

government_response.summary: The Government is committed to supporting alternatives to chemical pest control and recently consulted on a National Action Plan to minimise the risks and impacts associated with pesticides.
government_response.details:
The UK Government’s priority with regards to pesticides is to ensure that they will not harm people or wildlife, or pose unacceptable risks to the environment. To this end, we operate a strict system for regulating pesticides.

A pesticide may only be placed on the market in the UK if the product has been authorised by our regulator, the Health and Safety Executive, following a thorough risk assessment, which includes impacts on people, animals and the environment. If there are found to be unacceptable risks, to pollinators for example, the product is not authorised. The risk assessment also specifically addresses the situation of people living near where pesticides are used. Pesticide users are legally required to ensure that use is kept to the area to be treated and not allowed to drift onto neighbouring properties, and there are statutory conditions of use for all authorised pesticide products that must be followed. 

The Government is committed to supporting alternatives to chemical pesticides. In our 25 Year Environment Plan, the Government has outlined its approach to reducing the environmental impact of pesticides. Integrated Pest Management (IPM) lies at the heart of our approach to maximise the use of non-chemical control techniques and minimise the use of chemical pesticides. IPM is defined as the combined use of all available control methods. This means that pesticide users can take a holistic approach in reducing the associated risks (including indirect effects) whilst combating pest resistance. IPM also includes measures to optimise pesticide application, with the aim of reducing non target effects and unnecessary environmental exposure. This includes increasing the use of nature-based, low toxicity solutions and precision technologies, with the potential to enhance biodiversity, as well as benefit pollinators.   
 
Our approach is detailed in the draft revised ‘National Action Plan for the Sustainable Use of Pesticides’ (NAP), which sets out the ambition to improve indicators of pesticide usage, risk and impacts. This was the subject of a recent public consultation, with over 1,500 responses received and analysed. The summary of responses will be published in due course and the revised NAP later this year.  
  
The objective must be to reduce the risks and impacts associated with pesticides. These depend not only on the amount of pesticide used, but which pesticide is used and where use takes place. The draft revised NAP supports the development of low toxicity methods and improved advice and support for pesticides users, to reduce their impacts on human health and the environment.

We are also taking action alongside many partners to implement the National Pollinator Strategy’s provisions to help wild and managed pollinators to thrive. The Strategy sets out actions to address key risks and pressures, such as: habitat loss and fragmentation; invasive species; pests and disease; and climate change. This includes supporting IPM by restoring and creating habitats in rural and urban areas, including parks and gardens, and raising awareness across society so that people can take action themselves, by carefully considering whether or not to use pesticides in gardens, parks and other urban areas.

More broadly, our Environment Bill sets a new legal foundation for Government action to improve the environment. For example, it introduces Local Nature Recovery Strategies (LNRSs) to underpin the development of the Nature Recovery Network (NRN), an expanded and better-connected network of places that are richer in wildlife, more resilient to climate change and provide a range of benefits for people. LNRSs and the NRN Delivery Partnership, led by Natural England, will help bring people and organisations together at local and national levels to identify priorities and opportunities for nature recovery. We are integrating the goals for the network into a wide range of funding streams, including: land management schemes that reward environmental benefits; biodiversity net gain; and the Nature for Climate Fund.

Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban developments on Green belt and Greenfield sites across the country
attributes.background: Loss of green belt & greenfield sites for housing negatively affects the environment, releasing carbon from the land & losing that land's ability to capture new carbon. Wildlife and plant life already under stress, are displaced & loss of green spaces has a negative effect on communities.
attributes.additional_details: Houses proposed to be built have a great effect upon our environment. Contribute to pollution and in turn affect our planet. House development should take place on brown sites. The greenfield land, farm land, trees and wild flowers need protection now to encourage our planet to heal. All permissions for planned development of green belt or greenfield land should be revoked, and no further permissions granted.

government_response.summary: This Government is committed to maintaining existing Green Belt protections, enhancing Green Belt land quality, and promoting use of brownfield for new developments to reduce greenfield pressures.
government_response.details:
The Government currently offers strong protections for the Green Belt from development in national policy.  The National Planning Policy Framework states that a Green Belt boundary may be altered only in exceptional circumstances. Any proposal is subject to consultation with local people followed by rigorous and independent examination of the area’s Local Plan by a planning inspector. If a local authority cannot avoid the loss of Green Belt, it is expected to offset the loss of that land by environmental and access improvements to land remaining Green Belt. Furthermore, national planning policy states that most new developments in the Green Belt should be refused planning permission unless in very special circumstances, rightly determined by the local authority. As a result, the Government is not considering this proposal at this time.
  
As set out in the landmark Levelling Up White Paper, we are committed to enhancing the quality of land designated in the Green Belt. This means increasing public access to Green Belt, while simultaneously delivering nature recovery, in line with Environment Act commitments. This will provide improved access for those communities that currently lack good quality green space.

Department for Levelling Up, Housing & Communities

attributes.background: The government is consulting on a White Paper to change Planning Laws. It basically carves up the entirety of England into 3 zones. One will get automatic development rights. The second has presumption of development. Only the conservation and aonb areas etc will have methods of protection.
attributes.additional_details:
1.This White Paper says it will give community more input. We believe this is not true, and that the proposals are an assault on local democracy.
 
2. The paper says it is to help with housing shortages. We believe this is not true and that proposals are to help developers, as housing shortages are not to do with planning laws and there are a million unbuilt houses with permissions.
 
3. We believe these reforms will result in destruction of our countryside and urban green spaces, harm biodiversity.

attributes.action: Seek to agree upon equivalence of NHS Covid pass and European Covid Green Pass
attributes.background: From 12 August a European Green pass (equivalent to the NHS covid pass) will be needed to enter some public spaces (restaurants, clubs,etc) in some EU countries. Similarly, the NHS Covid pass is being required by some UK venues. The Government should agree equivalence of these passes with the EU.
attributes.additional_details: Currently vaccinations are not fully recognised between EU and UK and the various apps and systems are not talking to each other. This means that a British citizen going to a EU country may not be able to access public spaces in the EU and vice versa, and the European Green pass may not be recognised for European tourists in the UK.

attributes.action: Include funding for more school gardens in the 2020-21 school building programme
attributes.background: Ideally all schools should have a garden for health, systems learning, emotional & intellectual development, environmental resilience & sustainable work opportunities. Adapt a corner of a playground/sports field/car park to enable development of school curricula & fresh food for local communities.
attributes.additional_details: We know from decades of research globally that outdoor learning & 'garden school' pedgagogies are extremely beneficial for healthy development of children & youth, as well as for lifelong learning & health. We know from climate research that we urgently need to increase urban green space & protect biological diversity in our environment-locally, nationally & globally. Additionally, we know sustainable agricultural practices & food chains increase the resilience of local economies. A win-win.

attributes.action: Trial capping net immigration and then gradually reduce it to tens of thousands
attributes.background: The Government must cap immigration. To do so sensibly a trial period could be brought in and then the cap could be lowered over a few years. It could be done by capping the number of work visas, allowing only top 5% students to stay after studies, and more enforcement to deport overstayers.
attributes.additional_details: YouGov polls show the public is in favour of reducing net immigration levels. This should help fight the problems of housing shortage, loss of green spaces, road congestion and demand on public services at the core, rather than treating the symptoms. Previous Governments have pledged to lower immigration numbers, but plans to cap immigration have been abandoned. Even though it may entail temporary economic disadvantages, the numbers must be capped urgently accordingly to public demands.

attributes.action: Increase fixed penalty fines for littering
attributes.background: Penalties need to be increased to a level which shows that the authorities and society will no longer tolerate this antisocial, selfish behaviour, detrimental to the environment.
attributes.additional_details:
We have seen scenes across England of littered strewn parks, nature reserves, beaches and open spaces recently. Litter can have an effect on residents, people’s health, the economy, business, tourism, on crime and anti-social behaviour, and of course, on the environment.
 
'A Green Future: Our 25 Year Plan to Improve the Environment', sets out what the Government will do to improve the environment within a generation. Increasing consequences for littering could have an immediate positive environmental effect.

attributes.action: Work with councils to promote wildflower and grassland growth
attributes.background: The Government should work with local councils to promote the regrowth and rewilding of more green urban space.
attributes.additional_details:
This could involve reducing their grass mowing schedules. This could in turn have great effect on the populations of urban insects and mammals thus helping with wildlife right up the food chain.

I am very concerned about the state of urban greenspace. Though there are many wonderful designated greenspaces in urban areas there needs to be more focus on using all available land. For instance, the reduction of mowing on grass areas that do not need to be kept short would have a big impact. It would promote the growing of small wildflower and grassland areas all over urban areas. These would act as habitat and as migration routes for all manner of invertebrates and small mammals.

attributes.additional_details: Following the cost of living crisis, it makes logical sense to help tackle this with the introduction of fruit trees in parks such as apple trees. Not only is this good for the environment but will also help tackle the shortage of food and provide the public with a form of natural food.

attributes.action: Fund the planting of wildflowers along all public green spaces
attributes.background: We would like the Government pledge funding to plant a 1-meter wide strip of wildflowers along the length of every public green space (i.e. playing fields, grass verges etc). Councils would be allocated a grant to achieve this target. The target would be set by the Government.
attributes.additional_details:
The data shows the UK has experienced extinctions and declines in abundance, biomass and distribution of insects. Declines in abundance or distribution have been seen in bees and hoverflies, butterflies and moths, beetles, and freshwater insects. There are a variety of drivers behind insect decline, such as habitat loss, chemical use and climate change, and their impacts differ across habitat, species and time.
 
Source: UK Insect Decline and Extinctions, UK Parliament POST https://researchbriefings.files.parliament.uk/documents/POST-PN-0619/POST-PN-0619.pdf

attributes.action: Add green infrastructure as a nationally significant project to the Planning Act
attributes.background: The Planning Act is heavily focused on infrastructure, such as road, rail and energy. We need legislation that enables conservation bodies (Environment Agency, Natural England) to apply for planning consent, including compulsory acquisition, for green infrastructure for the good of the nation.
attributes.additional_details: Green infrastructure is a planned network of natural and semi-natural spaces with other environmental features designed to deliver a range of ecosystem services. The Government should do this to promote importance of the UK environment and conservation in its national planning. At present, the legislation is centred around mitigation, when there should be a greater promotion of new green infrastructure. It should be up to the planning authority to determine whether there is a 'Case for the Scheme' in the interest to the public. Currently there is no mechanism for green infrastructure schemes to come forward and be assessed.

We understand that you are concerned about the lack of undeveloped or green space in some towns, but it's not clear how the Government could implement your request, especially in towns where more than 80% of land is already developed.

attributes.action: Change planning and building regulations so new homes meet 21st century needs
attributes.background: Local people need more say over what kind of housing gets built where. Green spaces must not be destroyed to create estates of executive style 4/5 bedroomed houses when local people need 2/3 bedroomed houses or 1 or 2 bedroomed flats. Gas boilers must be banned immediately and source pumps fitted.
attributes.additional_details: The regulations are no longer fit for purpose in the light of the housing crisis, the climate emergency and the levelling-up agenda. Developers are using the green belt to build large executive style houses that a) do not solve the national housing shortage and b) hugely contribute to emissions. Too few affordable homes are built: developers claim they are not financially viable in order to focus on their profit margins. Too many young people and families cannot afford homes to rent or buy.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do.  We understand you'd like changes to planning regulations, but we're not sure from your petition exactly what changes you'd like to see happen. 

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Invest in the environmental infrastructure of the England.
attributes.background: It is time we start to address the decline of our planet by beginning at home, investing in the future wellbeing of our country through mass environmental projects, aimed at increasing the amount of green space (parks, national grounds, wildlands), and the reforesting of the Fells across England.
attributes.additional_details:
I hope you see the value of nature, if not, none of my words can convince you; however, if you do, then see that this is the moral and just thing to do. The amount of job creation would be substantial.

We can easily set an example, here in England to the rest of the world on what they too should be doing; Investing, not just to make more money, but to ensure future generations can thrive. Nature, has given us all we have. Can we please give back. You can do good, and gain the publics love.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you want to see more done to increase green space in the UK, but we're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

We have published the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

Introduce a National Reforestation Scheme: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/573066

Require developers felling trees to fund reforestation projects: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/578554

attributes.action: Overrule the new Gender recognition certificate law in Scotland
attributes.background: Overrule Nicola Sturgeon, the SNP and the Green Party in relation to lowering the age for a Gender Recognition Certificate and without an official diagnosis from a medical professional. Also to protect Womens spaces from being accessible to transgenders.
attributes.additional_details:
The new law will make it easier for
child abusers who have taken women’s rights from them through the Scottish Parliament! 

Scotland has made it very easy for sex pests, perverts and paedophiles to operate and there will be consequences. We need to protect the women and children of Scotland 

The majority of people in Scotland do not want these new rules and wish for our women and child to be safe.

rejection.details: We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. This is a decision for the Scottish Parliament.

attributes.action: Protect productive agricultural land and green belt from development in law
attributes.background: Bring in legal protection for  productive agricultural  and green belt land from development.
attributes.additional_details:
We need our prime agricultural land to grow sustainable high quality food which will cut our carbon foot print.  The soil where the crops are growing locks in carbon so is a big part of the fight against the Climate Emergency. The fields also provide habitats and hunting grounds for wildlife.
Green spaces provide a home for biodiversity to thrive also part of the solution to the Climate Crisis. They are also vital for people's health and well being.

rejection.details:
We understand you're concerned about development of greenbelt land, however it's not clear what legal protections you want to be introduced to protect such land. 

If there is a specific legal protection you would like to be brought in, you could start a petition about that.

You may like to sign this petition which calls for a related action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/575169

attributes.action: A overhaul of the littering policies. Start a take litter home campaign.
attributes.background: Commit to change culture and attitude to littering especially around our coastlines. Since lock down the benefits to the environment are undeniable, let's take the opportunity to smarten ourselves up. Take litter home campaign. Include this in your COVID campaign, it would be easy.
attributes.additional_details: Everyone appreciates clean green outdoor spaces, no one wants to see rubbish on the beaches. It's inexcusable. Environment impact. Now is the time to change bad habits.

rejection.details:
Increase penalties, enforcement and education to tackle littering & fly tipping:
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/324488

attributes.action: Recognise access to green space as a human right
attributes.background: Green spaces – with the mental and physical health benefits they provide – should be easily accessible for everyone. But this is not currently the case. 2.7M UK residents live over half a mile from a green space, with low-income and BAME communities most likely to suffer a deficit of local greenery.
attributes.additional_details:
The Government must declare access to green space a human right and take action to fulfil this right. This means protecting existing urban nature and increasing the volume of greenery in the areas where it is most needed (with pocket parks, street trees and biophilic architecture). 

COVID-19 has both awakened the nation’s appreciation for green spaces and exposed its stark disparities in access to them. We now have a chance to shape a healthier, happier and more equal society – let’s seize it.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do. We understand you'd like access to green space to be a human right, but we're not sure how you would like the Government to implement this. 
	
You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do, such as requiring planning laws to include a minimum amount of green space based on population.

attributes.action: Stop the reopening of the Stoke to Leek railway line.
attributes.background: We would like the government to block the reopening of this line that has been disused for 32 years.
attributes.additional_details:
This railway has been disused since 1988 and has grown into a peaceful wild life habitat. The huge amount of construction needed to reinstate the line would not only destroy this habitat,but these lives of many people who live adjacent to the line.
There are safety concerns for local school children going to and from school and also playing on the line and causing a danger to road users by dropping stones onto the road below bridges as has before.
It needs to stay as a green space.

rejection.details:
We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. 

You could raise your issue with a local councillor who represents you. You can use this page to find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them:

https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors

attributes.action: Stop construction of 5G masts in residential and environmentally sensitive areas
attributes.background: Stop Permitted Development, which allows  phone companies to erect 5G or future phone masts, in residential /  environmentally sensitive areas. Phone companies should replace and share existing masts on used brownfield sites rather than new sites. Councils and residents should always be consulted.
attributes.additional_details:
A mobile company recently applied to construct a 20m 5G mast on a residential green space impacting the local amenity. This green space includes several mature ash and lime trees, as well as protected wildlife. 

Residents raised 191 objections, plus an objection from the Council Tree Officer, resulting in the application being rejected.

However, under the new Planning Bill, neither the council nor the residents will be allowed to raise objections to developments of this kind.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do.  We're not sure if you want a ban on 5G masts in residential and environmentally sensitive areas, or for people to have the right to block proposals. 

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Plant trees with every new home built
attributes.background: I want the government to make it a condition of planning permission for developers creating new homes to be under obligation to plant a minimum of two trees per property created.
attributes.additional_details: Recently there have been several large developments approved in my local area of Sefton. Some of the developments have now completed areas of the properties. On a walk last week, I passed by such a development and I noticed that not one garden had a single tree in it. We are loosing green space at an alarming rate due to property development and whilst we are destroying the habitats of millions of creatures by doing this, the least we can do is pledge to give something back to the environment.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/572398

attributes.action: Stop the building of new homes along the A12 in Marks Gate
attributes.background: The Mayor of London has just given the green light for 300 new homes and flats to be built along the A12 and near Padnall Lake in Marks Gate - we want this development to be stopped.
attributes.additional_details: Marks Gate is already a residential estate, and has little green space - the local council are planning to build on the little green space the local era has along the lake and the busy A12. Over 100 people in Marks Gate are already on the housing list, building these flats and houses right next to people who are waiting for a better place to live is a mockery. This further removal of green space also takes away little green play area that younger local residents have access to.

rejection.details:
We can't accept your petition because the UK Government aren't responsible for the issue you raise. This is a matter for the London Assembly and the London Mayor.

The London Assembly has its own petitions process. You can find out more about how to petition the London Assembly here: https://www.london.gov.uk/about-us/london-assembly/petitions

attributes.action: Build More Children Play Equipment and Fitness Equipment in Green Spaces/Parks
attributes.background: The government have closed gyms and soft play and encouraged outdoor exercise but there has been no government facilitation. As a result play parks and the very limited amount of outdoor fitness equipment have became very widely used, counter productive to the entire concept of social distancing.
attributes.additional_details:
The government should actively build play parks and fitness equipment on all green spaces e.g. local parks in the cities. Each city council should place and maintain hand sanitisation stations in these areas.

Outdoor fitness equipment should also be provided particularly for teenagers and students in mind. e.g. pull up, parallel and monkey bars. Outdoor bouldering (similar to Cunningar Loop/Fairlop bouldering parks in Glasgow/London) and kayaking should also be facilitated on lochs/lakes.

rejection.details:
Local amenities, including play equipment and fitness equipment, are the responsibility of individual local authorities, not the Government or House of Commons.

We could accept a petition calling on the Government to provide additional funding to local authorities, for the purpose of increasing the amount of play equipment and fitness equipment in their localities.

attributes.action: Ban the sale and use of disposable BBQ's.
attributes.background: I would like to have these items removed from sale and have using them in a public place made illegal.
attributes.additional_details: Disposable BBQ's are responsible for many fires in the UK, in our local and national parks and areas of natural beauty. They are not actually very good at cooking and often used by people in an unsafe manner. They leave burns dotted about our green spaces that do not recover well as the soil is sterilised by the heat. They are often discarded thoughtlessly, while still alight, and create a significant hazard to wildlife and livestock. They also end up polluting rivers, lakes, fields and woods.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/315762

attributes.action: Maintain former Keighley college site as a large community green space.
attributes.background: Retain the former Keighley college site as a large green space, dramatically improving arrival into the town. Offering open space to promote well being, togetherness and a sense of community. Government to recognise the site as a community space and to not allow any construction upon the site .
attributes.additional_details: The former Keighley college site is now a large green space, dramatically improving the natural landscape upon arrival into the town . The site offer a huge opportunity to breath new life into the town and to be used to promote well being, togetherness and a sense of community .The site is owned by Bradford Metropolitan Council who have minimal interest in Keighley town centre. We call for the Government to recognise the site as a community space and to not allow any construction upon the site.

rejection.details:
We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. Local planning issues are the responsibility of your local council.

You could raise your issue with a local councillor who represents you. You can use this page to find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them:

https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors

You can also petition your local council - you can find out more here: 

https://www.bradford.gov.uk/your-council/epetitions/epetitions/

If you want the UK Government or Parliament to take action, for example to amend the legislation and policy framework which governs planning and development decisions taken by local authorities, you could start a new petition specifically asking for that action.

attributes.action: Prioritise the needs of local communities and limit the amount of new housing.
attributes.background: We want Parliament to acknowledge the people in local communities and involve them in discussions when it comes to spending on new housing compared to local services such as education, roads and towns, and a constant and open discussion between local MP's and the community on the topic of spending.
attributes.additional_details: We would like Parliament to take this into account because our local community have been affected by the many new housing estates because they have been built on precious green spaces while there is an empty town centre that is in need of an urgent renovation and the local council have focused their spending on additional housing rather than the foundations such as roads and education that are needed to support the influx of new homes.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/548391

attributes.action: Support an anti-litter awareness campaign
attributes.background: The easing of lockdown restrictions has seen some of the most beautiful scenic locations strewn with litter by members of the public who seem to have no thought or care for their actions. We urgently need the government to support a long term campaign to raise awareness of the impact of litter.
attributes.additional_details: For many years there has been a notable increase in the amount of litter being thrown with no thought of the environmental or financial cost. This change of attitude has culminated in scenic locations, green spaces and country lanes being strewn with litter. Those of us who lived through national campaigns by Keep Britain Tidy in the 1970s, can remember the impact and positive change that happened as a result. Now is the time for a new government backed campaign.

rejection.details:
We think this petition is similar:
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/324488

attributes.action: Stop housing developers building houses everywhere. Save YOUR local area!
attributes.background: Housing Developers are building a colossal amount of homes all over the UK. They are destroying towns and villages, overburdening the local infrastructures and destroying vital green space. Local councils need more power opposing this, and stronger rules are needed to protect these areas
attributes.additional_details:
Housing developers have the upper say in everything. Even if a plan is rejected by the councils, they are usually won on appeal,  costing the taxpayers thousands each time. County councils need to see the bigger picture and assess road surfaces and traffic. 
Roads are awful and gridlocked. Schools are full to bursting. In my area it is a three week wait for a GP appointment. Figures show 430 houses needed building between 2016 and 2019 - nearly 1100 were completed. Act now!!

rejection.details:
We understand that you are concerned about new housing developments, but it's not clear what action you want the Government to take about this. We can only accept petitions that request a clear action by the Government or Parliament.

We have published a related petition which you might like to sign: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/319314

You could also start a petition calling on the Government to require all new housing developments to be approved by the relevant local authority before they can go ahead, if that is what you want to happen.

attributes.action: Reopen the parks in Hammersmith and Fulham
attributes.background: Hammersmith and Fulham council have closed all the parks in the borough. Please reopen them for the health and sanity of the people of Hammersmith and Fulham.
attributes.additional_details: The Prime Minister himself has stated that parks should remain open so that people can exercise once a day. There is no reason for the parks of Hammersmith and Fulham to remain closed now that stronger policing is in place to stop people gathering in groups of more than two. The council are denying citizens the basic right to green space and daily exercise.

rejection.details:
Since you started your petition, the council has opened parks. 

In any case, this is not the responsibility of the UK Government or Parliament

With temperature soaring & with the uk wanting to cut the carbon foot print. destroying more brown or green which will have a huge impact on this is unacceptable. Not to mention More traffic more lighting all of which will increase carbon Plus with the impact on the nhs which is at breaking point with covid to add more pressure with the impact of people mental heath due to no gree space
